thread.title: Chapecoense's first overseas fixture since plane crash ends in victory as they beat Zulia in Venezuela
thread.title_full: Chapecoense's first overseas fixture since plane crash ends in victory as they beat Zulia in Venezuela

author: irishmirror
title: Chapecoense's first overseas fixture since plane crash ends in victory as they beat Zulia in Venezuela
text:
Sport Chapecoense's first overseas fixture since plane crash ends in victory as they beat Zulia in Venezuela Only six of the 77 people who were travelling to Colombia survived the tragedy in November, including three Chapecoense players Share Chapecoense were playing in their first overseas fixture since the plane crash (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) Share   Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Chapecoense beat Zulia 2-1 in the Copa Libertadores as the Brazilian club took part in an overseas fixture for the first time since the devastating plane crash which killed most of their squad. 
Only six of the 77 people who were travelling to Colombia survived the tragedy in November, including three Chapecoense players - goalkeeper Jackson Follmann, defender Neto and winger Alan Ruschel. 
In total 19 players and 24 other club members died as the plane crashed into a mountain near the city of Medellin. 
The team had been on its way to take part in the Copa Sudamerica final - the title of the competition was subsequently awarded to them after the incident. Chapecoense line up before the game (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) Joao Pedro and Zulia's Yohandry Orozco in action (Photo: REUTERS) Chapecoense celebrate after Reinaldo's goal (Photo: REUTERS) 
On an emotional night in north-east Venezuela, Neto and Ruschel were named in the squad but did not feature. 
Reinaldo opened the scoring and Luiz Antonio doubled the lead with 21 minutes remaining at Estadio Jose Encarnacion Pachencho Romero. Luiz Antonio celebrates after scoring (Photo: AFP) Douglas Grolli and Andrei Girotto vie for the ball (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) Chapecoense players applaud the fans at full time (Photo: AFP) 
Juan Arango pulled a goal back nine minutes later but Chapecoense claimed an historic victory, just over three months since the disaster. 
Chapecoense drew 2-2 against Brazilian champions Palmeiras in their first match since the air disaster in January. Like us on Facebook
